awd_titl_txt: Quasi-Locality Properties of Quantum Many-Body Dynamics and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
A variety of fundamental phenomena can be modeled mathematically as systems of many interacting components. The problem of analyzing the dynamics of any such system becomes tractable if we recognize that individual components interact primarily with only a small number of "nearby" components. This is referred to as a quasi-locality property of the system. At the microscopic level, the basic laws of quantum physics govern the dynamics of systems consisting of atoms and elementary particles. Much of the recent progress made in understanding the dynamics of such systems has been through the mathematical analysis of their quasi-locality properties. In this project, new mathematical advances exploiting the quasi-locality properties of quantum systems will be used to obtain a better understanding of the physical systems of interest for new quantum technologies. In particular, new methods will be developed to allow more precise modeling of the quantum systems employed for quantum information processing and computation.

Quantum many-body systems at low temperatures describe a fascinating array of behavior generically described as quantum states of matter. This project will deepen the mathematical understanding of so-called gapped phases. Systems in a gapped phase have one or more ground states and a spectral gap for excitations in the bulk. One important goal of the project is to understand how the excitation spectrum of such systems can be described as a system of quasi-particles. In particular for systems in two space dimensions these quasi-particles may be anyons, instead of the more commonly encountered fermions and bosons. Techniques will be developed, based on the fundamental quasi-locality properties of the dynamics, to prove the existence of anyons, their relation to topological order in the ground state(s), and their dynamical properties. These problems are motivated by the desire to learn more about the quantum states of matter that occur in condensed matter systems, and to understand better the potential of topologically ordered materials in applications such as quantum memory and other quantum devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

Quasi-locality properties of mathematical theories of many-particle systems express a fundamental principle of the natural world. Turning this locality principle into effective mathematical techniques was the main focus of this research. The PI and his collaborators accomplished the following three specific goals: A) Extending properties of and techniques using quasi-local maps; B) Proving stability theorems for fermionic and bosonic lattice systems; C) Studying new phenomena in one-dimension systems, in particular, disordered quantum spin chains. The new results obtained in this projects appeared in thirteen peer-reviewed publications and were reported in over two dozen conference talks, posters, and lecture series.

 

Intellectual Merit

The first leg of the project resulted in a comprehensive treatment of quasi-local maps in the context of quantum spin systems, which was well received by the broader research community. This was followed by a study of analogous properties of lattice fermion system. In a next step the PI and collaborators then studied fermion systems in continuum space, which allows for the inclusion for more realistic features of the dynamics of electrons in a solid. A second direction of investigation was the stability question of insulator phases. The project developed general criteria of stability of the spectral gap above ground states of lattice systems that include the case of systems with gapless boundary modes. Of the latter, quantum Hall systems are an interesting class of fascinating examples. The project resulted in the first mathematical proof of the long-standing conjecture that the truncated Haldane pseudo-potential Hamiltonian has a spectral gap above the ground state for the case of the 1/3 filled first Landau level.

 

Broader Impacts

The core concepts and techniques of mathematical physics of many-particle systems form an excellent foundation for further application-oriented research in many areas, including current developments in information and data science. Indeed the historical origin of the mathematical methods now successfully employed in modeling problems for the new quantum technologies, the principle concepts in quantum information theory, and the foundations of the data science revolution, all go back to the mathematics of statistical mechanics. To further this fruitful interplay between foundations and applications, the PI helped design a new course in the mathematics of quantum information theory, primarily aimed at graduate students in pure and applied mathematics, but also with the explicit purpose of complementing the new classes on related topics created by colleagues in the departments of Physics, Computer Science, and Electrical and Computer Engineering.

The Covid-19 pandemic allowed only restricted options for effective mentoring of students. New students in particular were impacted by the difficulties posed by limited direct personal interaction. It is more difficult to provide meaningful career advice to students one has only met by Zoom. Nevertheless, mathematics majors at all levels continue to enjoy a high degree of full-time employment after graduation. In the course of this project, two graduate students obtained their PhD degrees. The PI also guided about half-a-dozen bachelor students in research and capstone projects.
